name: International Baccalaureate (IB)
description: The IB Diploma Programme is a rigorous, academically challenging and balanced pre-university curriculum for students aged 16-19. It emphasizes critical thinking, intercultural understanding, and exposure to a variety of viewpoints.

grading.scale: 1-7 per subject, 45 points maximum (6 subjects + 3 core points)

assessmentPhilosophy: IB assessment is criterion-referenced, meaning students are evaluated against fixed standards rather than against each other. Assessment combines external examinations (typically 70-80% of final grade) with internally assessed coursework (20-30%). The IB emphasizes developing students who can think critically, apply knowledge to new situations, and communicate ideas effectively. Questions often require extended responses demonstrating deep understanding rather than memorization.

keyTerminology.TOK: Theory of Knowledge - a core course exploring the nature of knowledge
keyTerminology.EE: Extended Essay - a 4000-word independent research paper
keyTerminology.CAS: Creativity, Activity, Service - core requirement for experiential learning
keyTerminology.IA: Internal Assessment - coursework marked by teachers and moderated by IB
keyTerminology.SL: Standard Level - 150 teaching hours over 2 years
keyTerminology.HL: Higher Level - 240 teaching hours over 2 years, greater depth
keyTerminology.AHL: Additional Higher Level - extra content for HL students
keyTerminology.IBO: International Baccalaureate Organization - the governing body
keyTerminology.Rubric: Detailed marking criteria for specific assessments

commandTerms.definition: Give a specific name, value or other brief answer without explanation or calculation
examples: State the function of mitochondria
State the formula for velocity

commandTerms.definition: Give the precise meaning of a word, phrase, concept or physical quantity
examples: Define activation energy
Define natural selection

commandTerms.definition: Give a sequence of brief answers with no explanation
examples: List three factors affecting enzyme activity

commandTerms.definition: Give a brief account or summary
examples: Outline the process of DNA replication

commandTerms.definition: Give a detailed account including characteristics and main features
examples: Describe the structure of a cell membrane

commandTerms.definition: Make clear the differences between two or more concepts or items
examples: Distinguish between mitosis and meiosis

commandTerms.definition: Give a detailed account including reasons or causes
examples: Explain how enzymes catalyze reactions

commandTerms.definition: Use knowledge and understanding in response to a given situation or real circumstances
examples: Apply the concept of natural selection to antibiotic resistance

commandTerms.definition: Obtain a numerical answer showing the relevant stages in the working
examples: Calculate the magnification of the microscope

commandTerms.definition: Break down in order to bring out the essential elements or structure
examples: Analyse the data in the graph to identify trends

commandTerms.definition: Give an account of the similarities between two or more items, referring to both throughout
examples: Compare aerobic and anaerobic respiration

commandTerms.definition: Give an account of similarities and differences between two or more items, referring to both throughout
examples: Compare and contrast DNA and RNA structure

commandTerms.definition: Offer a considered and balanced review that includes a range of arguments, factors or hypotheses. Conclusions should be presented clearly and supported by appropriate evidence
examples: Discuss the ethical implications of genetic engineering

commandTerms.definition: Make an appraisal by weighing up the strengths and limitations
examples: Evaluate the effectiveness of vaccination programs

commandTerms.definition: Propose a solution, hypothesis or other possible answer
examples: Suggest reasons for the unexpected results

commandTerms.definition: Reach a conclusion from the information given
examples: Deduce the genotype of the parent from the offspring ratios

commandTerms.definition: Give valid reasons or evidence to support an answer or conclusion
examples: Justify your conclusion with reference to the data

commandTerms.definition: Consider the merits or otherwise of an argument or concept. Opinions and conclusions should be presented clearly and supported with appropriate evidence and sound argument
examples: To what extent does climate change affect biodiversity?
